text: Princes shall come out of Egypt; Ethiopia shall soon stretch out her hands unto God.
text_kjv: Princes shall come out of Egypt; Ethiopia shall soon stretch out her hands unto God.
text_niv: Envoys will come from Egypt;Cush will submit herself to God.
text_esv: Nobles shall come from Egypt; Cush shall hasten to stretch out her hands to God.
text_nlt: Let Egypt come with gifts of precious metals ;let Ethiopia bring tribute to God.
text_msg: Let Egyptian traders bring blue clothand Cush come running to God, her hands outstretched.
text_nasb: Envoys will come out of Egypt; Ethiopia will quickly stretch out her hands to God.
context: Psalm 68 is a victory psalm, likely composed for a procession bringing the Ark of the Covenant to its resting place in Jerusalem. Its authorship is traditionally attributed to David, though some scholars suggest later origins. The psalm celebrates God's power, majesty, and faithfulness to His people, Israel. It recalls God's deliverance of Israel from Egyptian slavery and His continued protection and provision. Verse 31 specifically addresses the nations surrounding Israel. Egypt, a historical oppressor, and Ethiopia (Cush in Hebrew), representing distant, often hostile lands south of Egypt, are mentioned. Historically, Egypt's power waxed and waned, but it consistently posed a political and military threat to Israel. Ethiopia, while geographically distant, had intermittent contact with Israel, sometimes through trade and occasionally through conflict. The mention of 'princes' from Egypt highlights the submission or alliance of Egyptian leadership. The act of 'stretching out hands' in ancient Near Eastern cultures signified supplication, worship, or submission to a superior power. The verse, therefore, speaks of a future time when even these nations, historically either hostile or pagan, would acknowledge and turn to the God of Israel. This foreshadows the universal reach of God's kingdom, extending beyond the borders of Israel to include all nations.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 68:31 signifies the universality of God's redemptive plan. It transcends the immediate context of Israel's victories and points towards a future where all nations acknowledge God's sovereignty. The mention of Egypt, a symbol of oppression and paganism in the Old Testament, turning to God suggests the transformative power of divine grace. It demonstrates that even the most hardened hearts and the most resistant nations can be reached by God's love. The reference to Ethiopia stretching out her hands to God further emphasizes this global scope. Ethiopia, representing the ends of the earth and the distant Gentile nations, signifies that God's salvation is not limited to the descendants of Abraham but is offered to all who call upon His name. This verse anticipates the fulfillment of the Abrahamic covenant, where God promised that all nations would be blessed through Abraham's offspring (Genesis 12:3). It also foreshadows the New Testament concept of the Great Commission (Matthew 28:19-20), where Jesus commands His followers to go and make disciples of all nations. The image of nations stretching out their hands to God speaks of a voluntary submission and a recognition of God's ultimate authority. It's not a forced conversion but a genuine turning of the heart towards the one true God. This verse therefore speaks of hope, reconciliation, and the ultimate triumph of God's kingdom on earth.
application: Psalm 68:31 has profound implications for modern-day Christians. Firstly, it challenges us to have a global perspective on God's work. We are called to pray for and support missions and ministries that reach out to diverse cultures and nations, just as Ethiopia stretched out her hands to God. We should actively participate in sharing the Gospel with those who have not yet heard the Good News, recognizing that God's love extends to every corner of the earth. Secondly, the verse encourages us to be open to reconciliation and forgiveness. Just as Egypt, a former oppressor of Israel, is prophesied to turn to God, we too should be willing to extend grace and forgiveness to those who have wronged us. We should seek to build bridges of understanding and reconciliation, even with those who may hold different beliefs or come from different backgrounds. Thirdly, the verse calls us to examine our own hearts and ensure that we are genuinely stretching out our hands to God in worship and submission. Are we truly seeking God's will in our lives, or are we clinging to idols of wealth, power, or worldly success? Do we come before Him with humility and a desire to follow His commands? Fourthly, Psalm 68:31 speaks to the power of prayer. We are called to intercede for nations and peoples who are far from God, trusting that He can transform even the most hardened hearts. We should pray for peace, justice, and the spread of the Gospel in all nations. Finally, this verse is a reminder of God's ultimate victory. Despite the challenges and difficulties we face in the world, we can be confident that God's kingdom will ultimately prevail. We can look forward to a future where all nations will worship Him together in unity and peace.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the promise of Psalm 68:31, that even nations like Egypt and Ethiopia will one day turn to you. We pray for the fulfillment of this prophecy in our own time. We ask that you would soften the hearts of leaders and peoples around the world, that they may recognize your sovereignty and submit to your loving rule. We lift up those nations where the Gospel is suppressed or where Christians face persecution. Give them strength and courage to stand firm in their faith. Lord, help us to be your ambassadors of reconciliation and peace, building bridges of understanding and sharing your love with all whom we encounter. May our lives be a testament to your grace and your transformative power. Help us to continuously stretch our hands toward you in humble submission and adoration. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: The verse doesn't guarantee individual salvation for all Egyptians or Ethiopians. It symbolizes the inclusion of all nations in God's redemptive plan, implying a significant turning towards God from these historically pagan regions. It's a picture of God's universal reach.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Does this verse mean Egypt and Ethiopia are 'saved'?

faqs.answer: While elements of this prophecy have been partially fulfilled throughout history, the complete and universal submission of all nations to God is likely a future event, possibly linked to the culmination of God's kingdom on earth.
faqs.question: Q2: Is this prophecy already fulfilled, or is it yet to come?

faqs.answer: This verse provides scriptural support for the Great Commission (Matthew 28:19-20). It shows that God's desire is for all nations to know Him and worship Him, which is the very essence of the Great Commission.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the Great Commission?

faqs.answer: Stretching out your hands to God is a gesture of supplication, submission, worship, and dependence. It signifies a willingness to receive from God and to acknowledge His authority over your life.
faqs.question: Q4: What does it mean to 'stretch out your hands' to God?

faqs.answer: You can apply this verse by praying for global missions, supporting cross-cultural ministries, seeking reconciliation with those who are different, and examining your own devotion to God.
faqs.question: Q5: How should I apply this verse in my own life practically?
